Stimulants
Stimulants are medications that increase activity in the parts of the brain that control attention and behaviour. They are often used in conjunction with cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT). Stimulants increase the levels of dopamine and norepinephrine in your brain. This improves your focus and reduces the effects of certain impulses, such as those that trigger impulsive behavior. Stimulants are generally well tolerated by children and adults but some people may have negative effects, including jitteriness, headaches or an increased heart rate.
There are a number of different stimulant medications available, including methylphenidate (Ritalin) and dextroamphetamine (Dexamphetamine) as well as atomoxetine (Strattera) and modafinil (Provigil). A medical issue such as thyroid disorders, sleep apnea or other conditions could be causing your child’s fatigue or difficulty concentrating. Many medical professionals recommend that children are medicated for ADHD to enhance their school performance and allow for them to develop into happy, healthy adults. However the decision to treat a child with ADHD is not considered lightly by parents and can be a long and complicated process.
